It is understandable to feel concerned about the use of drones by law enforcement agencies and whether they will follow the regulations and guidelines in place. However, it is important to note that the use of drones by police for surveillance purposes is heavily regulated to ensure that they are used appropriately and within the bounds of the law. 

There are specific laws and regulations in place that govern the use of drones by police, including the Fourth Amendment of the US Constitution and FAA regulations. Additionally, various privacy laws have been enacted at the state and federal levels to protect citizens' privacy rights.

Furthermore, the use of drones by police is subject to oversight by various entities, including courts and legal institutions, to ensure that their use is within the parameters of the law. Policymakers and advocacy groups have also played a role in shaping laws and regulations governing the use of drones by police.

If you have concerns about the use of drones for surveillance purposes by police agencies in your area, you may wish to reach out to legal organizations or advocacy groups that can provide guidance or report any violations to the appropriate authorities.
